channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Defiant Pakistani Ex-Leader Denounces Treason Trial
item.description: The former military ruler Pervez Musharraf called the case the worst kind of “political vendetta” and claimed the country’s military establishment was upset by his treatment.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Bangladesh’s Political Crisis Grows
item.description: The government closed most forms of transportation into the capital, arrested hundreds and barred the main opposition alliance from holding a protest rally.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Syria to Miss Deadline for Moving Chemical Weapons
item.description: Volatile security and bad weather are among the factors contributing to the delay, says a report by the United Nations and a watchdog group.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Egypt May Elect President Before Voting for Parliament
item.description: Analysts said the move being considered by the interim president to switch the order of elections could allow Egypt’s leaders to maintain tighter control over the outcomes.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Matchmaker’ Investment Agencies Help Open the Door to China
item.description: As China’s outbound direct investment increases and becomes ever more visible, times are good for third-party agencies that can bridge the cultural and linguistic gaps to reach Chinese investors.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The Beijing headquarters of China National Offshore Oil Corporation, whose $15.1 billion takeover of the Canadian oil and gas company Nexen was approved by the Canadian government in December 2012 and by United States regulators in February 2013.

item.title: Antigovernment March Draws Diverse Group of Protesters in Cambodia
item.description: The march included protesters with a diverse list of grievances: Buddhist monks, garment workers, farmers and supporters of the main opposition party.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters in the Cambodian capital included Buddhist monks, garment workers, farmers and supporters of the main opposition party.

item.title: At Least 15 Are Killed in Explosion at Russian Rail Station
item.description: The explosion struck the main station in Volgograd, raising the specter of terrorism ahead of the Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Investigators worked near the body of a victim following an explosion at a train station in Volgograd, Russia, on Sunday.

item.title: Rocket Fired From Lebanon Lands in Israel
item.description: There were no injuries in the attack, but there were fears it could disturb a fragile cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: An Israeli explosives expert carried the remains of a rocket that landed near the town of Kiryat Shimona on Sunday.

item.title: Fears of Social Breakdown as Gambling Explodes in Italy
item.description: Critics blame the concentration of gambling machines for an increase in chronic gambling — and debt, bankruptcies, depression, domestic violence and broken homes — recorded by social service workers in Pavia, Italy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man played a slot machine in a bar in Pavia.

item.title: Polling Comes to Afghanistan, Suggesting Limit to Sway of President Karzai
item.description: Three recent polls are giving Afghans a crash course in front-runners, horse-race coverage and candidates who eagerly dismiss any numbers that do not put them out front, topics familiar to Americans.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An image of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan in Kabul. He has not endorsed a successor.

item.title: Russia Screening of Pussy Riot Film Is Blocked
item.description: Directors of a state-financed theater in Moscow received a call from authorities threatening their jobs if they screened a documentary about the activist group.
item.dc:creator: By MELENA RYZIK

item.title: New Law All but Bars Russian GPS Sites in U.S.
item.description: A measure that was signed into law on Thursday virtually bars Moscow from building monitor stations on American soil that critics feared could be used for snooping or worse.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Deadly Syrian Bomb Strikes Crowded Aleppo Market
item.description: At least 21 people were killed at a market as government forces kept up a bombing campaign.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A child was rescued Saturday from a collapsed building in Aleppo. At least 21 people were killed in an attack on a market.

item.title: Civilians Trying to Flee South Sudan Violence Are Caught Between Two Sides
item.description: Those who have sought shelter at a United Nations base are nursing wounds and fighting hunger and disease.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Othom Bol with his daughter Nyauny, 6, who was shot at the United Nations base in Malakal, South Sudan.

item.title: Deadly Shootout and Arrest in Iraq Set Off Sunni Protests
item.description: A raid by Iraqi security forces on the home of a prominent Sunni member of Parliament on Saturday morning in Anbar Province set off a two-hour gun battle that left the lawmaker’s brother and five guards dead, along with a soldier, Iraqi security and medical officials said.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Civilians Trying to Flee South Sudan Violence Are Caught Between Two Sides
item.description: Those who have sought shelter at a United Nations base are nursing wounds and fighting hunger and disease.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Shots Fired Before 4 Were Held in Libya
item.description: The holding of four American military personnel on Friday was preceded by a confrontation at a checkpoint, a witness and an Obama administration official said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: New Study Refines View of Sarin Attack in Syria
item.description: A new analysis of rockets linked to the chemical attack on Damascus in August concluded that they were most likely fired by multiple launchers and had a range of about three kilometers.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: An image taken by local activists in Damascus shows the remains of a rocket implicated in a chemical attack in August.

item.title: A Civil Servant in Mexico Tests U.S. on Asylum
item.description: Mexican officials have become frustrated by a local official who has provided residents with letters describing their area’s drug violence to help them seek asylum in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz-Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: C. Ramon Contreras Orozco is a local official in La Ruana.

item.title: Projects Under Scrutiny Displace Istanbul’s Poor
item.description: Development projects like the ones at the center of a widening corruption investigation in Turkey have left migrants from the countryside wondering where they will go.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebuilt houses on one side of a street in the Suleymaniye district of Istanbul, and decrepit ones on the other. Government development projects “will only be for rich people,” one resident said.

item.title: A Protester Is Killed During Campus Violence in Egypt
item.description: One demonstrator was confirmed dead on Saturday after a clash between police officers and student supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood on the eastern Cairo campus of Al-Azhar University.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A building at Al-Azhar University in Cairo was set on fire Saturday during protests by supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood.

item.title: Members of Jewish Student Group Test Permissible Discussion on Israel
item.description: Swarthmore’s Hillel rebelled this month, saying it would not abide by its parent group’s guidelines prohibiting collaboration with speakers or groups deemed unsupportive of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Jessica Kourkounis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swarthmore’s Hillel group decided not to abide by guidelines prohibiting collaboration with speakers or groups deemed unsupportive of Israel.

item.title: In Textbook Fight, Japan Leaders Seek to Recast History
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s government has begun to pursue a more openly nationalist agenda on an issue that critics fear will push the country further from its postwar pacifism.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taketomi is resisting a textbook that it considers too revisionist on World War II.

item.title: Deadly Mix in Benghazi: False Allies, Crude Video
item.description: The reality behind the deadly attack on American outposts in Libya is murkier and more complex than initially believed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Signs of a Russian Thaw (Toward Business)
item.description: In a country where entrepreneurs are scorned (or worse), an influential voice is speaking up for them — carefully.
item.dc:creator: By JOSHUA YAFFA
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruslan Telkov outside a warehouse near Moscow that he rented for his fabrics business. He was charged with copyright infringement in 2011.
